DOC.brief_summary: The diagnosis of abuse in children relies heavily on the presence of skeletal and extraskeletal injuries. However, some lesions are not seen by initial skeletal survey. And the investigators have to complete the skeletal survey with either bone-scan or CT scan or whole-body MRI. whole-body MRI has proved its worth in the pediatric population for the evaluation of skeletal and extraskeletal lesions in children with cancer or infectious diseases. Thus, whole-body MRI would allowed to have total picture of children without ionising radiation exposure.
DOC.brief_title: Utility of Whole-body MRI in the Detection of Traumatic Injuries of Undetermined Origin in Children
DOC.criteria: Infant hospitalised for subdural hematoma or skeletal injuries due to non accidental traumatism or skin lesions or abdominal injuries of undetermined origin Subdural hematoma of accidental origin or skeletal injuries of accidental Origin or known origin of lesions. Subject already included in the study
